segments.text: Okay, you were saying that the students in the square were receiving support from the other people in the city of Beijing.
A sense of camaraderie, you're suggesting.
And you were just telling me that the older generation had a feeling of admiration, maybe, and wishing they had been willing to speak up.
That's what was beginning to dawn on them.
And the students acted as the catalyst.

The students were very politically wise in the sense that at the beginning, their comments were focused more at the government's treatment of the students in the university and wanting better conditions at the university.
Like the poor cafeterias you were talking about.
Poor cafeterias and living conditions and that.
But they broadened their criticisms.
to include corruption that was going on in the government.
And we have to remember here that the students were not, and the people in Beijing, were not advocating to overthrow the government.
This was a very peaceful demonstration.

The students knew that they had to keep things peaceful because if there was any even hint of civil unrest, if they set any cars on fire or were throwing bricks through any windows, as we've seen happen in some other countries,
that that would give the government the excuse they needed to use whatever level of force that they wanted to put down the demonstration.
So the students did everything you would possibly to completely control what was going on so that nothing got out of hand, so that no fights broke out, so that there wasn't any real trouble.
The students broadened their comments to include things that
people from broader sectors of society could relate to.
The corruption, as I mentioned, that there was going on in the government where people at high levels of government who were supposed to be looking out for the good of the people were not.
They were using their position to their own advantage and to their family's advantage monetarily.
And the people were also
beginning to realize, I think, that they could actually make some decisions for themselves.

Throughout Chinese history, through Confucianism, through their culture, that they had been trained to give their allegiance to the leader, the emperor and the people under him, all the way down to the family unit.
The father was the absolute head of the family.
You didn't question, you didn't disagree with what the person of authority above you told you.
You just were totally submissive to that.
You did whatever they said.
And I think what has happened over the thousands of years that they have done is the people have subconsciously let themselves become dependent upon their leaders and they felt that they
needed the leaders to make the decisions for them and to provide a place for them to live, to provide food, to provide clothing and that for them.
And the older generation in particular, I think, during the 80s and the limited amount of economic freedom that they had, were beginning to
realized that they did not need to rely on leaders to make all the decisions for them.
They were beginning to get a feeling of self-confidence, that they could actually make some decisions for themselves.
And they wanted the government, again, there's no opposition party.
They were not asking to overthrow the government.
They were asking the government to be more responsive to their needs and to allow them a little bit more control
over their lives.
For example, the government would decide when a person could get married, where they could have children, where they would live, where they would work.
Things that we in this country take for granted as basic freedom of choice.
People do not have that.
When you were there in 85, 86 and had a chance to enter
In your work with some of the students, you got a very clear feeling of this.
You work where the government gives you a job after graduation and so forth.

Carrying over that sense of understanding of the students, a little while ago you mentioned that you felt somehow a sense of the group as a whole wanting to keep things peaceful, not wanting to get things out of hand.
Could you be specific at what gave you that feeling as you were watching from the sidelines or walking around?

Well, in these groups, during the day, there were smaller crowds within Tiananmen Square in the evening, partly because people worked during the day, and I think partly because, again, the students and the Chinese people felt that if the government was going to do something, they were going to do it at night.
And so in the early evening, a lot of people would start coming to Tiananmen Square.
Now, there's not a whole lot of entertainment things to do in Beijing anyway.
And Tiananmen Square, in the summertime, is a place where people can go.
It's out in the open, so there is some breeze.
So it's cooler than it is in the high rise apartments that they have.
But because the demonstrations weren't going on, of course, there's a lot of curiosity.
And people would come there in the evenings.
And one evening, on a Friday evening, I had gone with some friends to eat at a restaurant near Tiananmen Square.
And we tried coming down Chinatown Avenue in a car to see what was going on at Tiananmen Square.
And three blocks before we even got to Tiananmen Square, Chinatown Avenue was completely filled with people.
So we had to go.
Not vehicles.
You're talking about people.
I'm talking about people.
so we had to go around the Forbidden City behind that to get back towards our hotel.
And yet, even though you had this large group of people, they were not unruly.
Students were continually going around.
You would see small groups, and they would be telling people what was happening, what was going on.
As a matter of fact, throughout Beijing, you would see students with small groups of people around them, and the students were
putting posters up on telephone poles and that for people to read so they could know what had been going on, what had been transpiring, or talking with these groups.
And if you compare it to going to a college football game here in the United States, you get a certain amount of rowdiness and shoving and pushing, but there was none of that going on.
Even though you had
for larger numbers of people, it was still very peaceful.
And the Saturday evening, I...
Excuse me, that would be Saturday evening, the 3rd of June?
Okay.
This was the evening the massacre started.
I had been out to the Great Wall that day.
This was the last day of our conference, and they had arranged for buses to take us out there.
And we had gotten back
to Beijing about 5 o'clock in the afternoon and I had heard that the students had been tear gassed during the day.
So I thought I would make my way to Tiananmen Square to see if the situation had changed from when I had been there the day before.
Excuse me, you went out by yourself.
So I went out by myself.
I did not want to go directly to Tiananmen Square because with

that large amount of people and we knew that there were troops soldiers in the train station which is about three blocks from channel square i did not want to get caught in the middle so it was i took this is where having lived in beijing for a year was was helpful to me in that i knew my way around the city and i felt that i would be able to sense any real danger or spot any real danger
soon enough that I could find a way out of the situation.
So I took a cab to the Friendship Store, which is about a mile and a half east of Tiananmen Square on the main avenue, Chandler Avenue.
And when I got there, there were people going both directions towards the square and coming from the square.
No one seemed to be unduly
concerned or worried.
In the early evenings, because a lot of people would congregate in Tiananmen Square, the bus and automobile traffic would be stopped.
And it was already, there were hardly any cars or buses going down.
So I decided what I'd do is I would walk towards Tiananmen Square
And that way, if anything started happening, I would be able to see it and get out of the way.
About halfway down, I saw a group of about 25 soldiers who were, I think, just out for some daily exercise.
They were about 100 yards ahead of me.
And I watched them as they went down the street.
And they crossed.
I was on the north side of Cheltenham Avenue, which is
on eight-lane roads.
This is a major street.
And they crossed that and went into one of the, down one of the side avenues there.
And I did not see them.
The people were walking by, didn't pay much attention to them.
These were wearing soldiers carrying guns.
Oh, yeah, they were in uniforms.
These did not have guns.
They were just out marching around.
Okay.
I said, I think they were just out for some daily exercise, and so they went back towards the direction of the train station.
So it took me about an hour and a half to walk down to Tiananmen Square.
I got there about 7 o'clock in the evening.
And things looked peaceful.
I could not really tell any difference in terms of the tents and the gas democracy flags and that that were flying.
And I walked around the square and then decided to just observe what was going on.
I got myself on the east side of Tiananmen Square because I felt that that had the most options for me in terms of avenues of escape to get out of there if anything started happening.
And just sat there and watched the people.
as more and more people started coming into the square.
Most of the people, I said, in China, they get around on bicycles.
And I was struck by the fact that here were people, there were young couples who were out on a date, teenagers, families, a father, a mother, a small child.
They have these three-wheeled bicycles that have kind of a big seat in the back.
And the father would be pedaling.
The wife and the child would be in the back.
And even some older couples were riding their bicycles around Tiananmen Square to see what was going on.
Some of it was probably curiosity.
And part of it was to support the students in what was going on.
It reminded me of a Saturday night of people cruising around the Dairy Queen.
All of these people and all this activity was very, very peaceful.
And I was struck by the fact that there were four ambulances that were parked right over near me.
And they had a big sign on the side of them that they had been provided by the government of Italy.
And I thought across my head, why had the United States done something like this?
Why had we provided
some kind of care like this.
And as a matter of fact, one of the students, while I was sitting there, apparently had passed out.
And several of his friends had picked him up and put him on one of these Trishaw bicycles and brought him over to the ambulance, and the ambulance took him off towards the hospital.
But the students were gathered mainly around the
to the Heroes of the People, which is in the back part of the square in front of Miles Mausoleum.
And they were using their own loudspeaker system that they had to talk to the large group.
There are also the light poles around Tiananmen Square are speakers.
And the government was using that to get its own message across.
I wish now that I had taken the tape recorder along and taped some of that so I could have translated, but I didn't do that.
After watching all this for about an hour, everything was so peaceful in a way it was boring.
There wasn't, you know, I watched it and there wasn't anything dramatic happening.
Can I ask, you're obviously different in size than most Orientals.
You're over six foot.
different in appearance, did that make you stand out, or did they respond to you?
Well, people, they recognize that you're foreign.
You can't hide that.
Height is not so much a factor with the Chinese as it is with the Japanese.
The Japanese are much more uniform with their height, about 5'2", 5'3".
But the Chinese, there are a lot of Chinese that are 6 feet and taller, so
My height was not particularly standing out.
But, of course, the color of your skin and your eyes and that, you're obviously not Chinese.
So they knew you were a foreigner.
Oh, yes.
But the people of Beijing, you see, they've been exposed to foreigners for eight or ten years, whereas some of the places that we went while we were in China, there was one village where...
We may have been some of the first foreigners that they saw.
And Taylor, our youngest, said two and a half with very blonde hair.
He really attracted attention.
That may have been the first foreign child that these people had ever seen.
The people of Beijing, you don't stick out as much.
I think what they were looking for in terms of foreigners, though, were particularly people who were the foreign press.
And they realized that
They needed to let the world know what was going on, because the Chinese government wasn't going to tell the people the truth.
So they felt that they were very receptive to foreign press

uh being there you mentioned though that you had a camera um that might have given you the aura of possibly being media if they didn't i took some pictures of that but but uh no one you know came up and tried to initiate any conversation with me at that point so you kind of sat for an hour an hour and a half watching what was going on what happened then and my uh
daughter and older son were going to leave from the Houston airport the next morning.
It would be Sunday morning, my time in Beijing, Saturday here in the States.
And it would be Sunday evening in Beijing time, Sunday morning back here in the States.
So I decided I'd go ahead back to my hotel and call back home one last time.
because that would be Saturday morning here, and tell them everything is OK. Come on over, and I'll get you at the airport.
So they have some little trishaw bicycles that people also use to earn some extra money as kind of taxicabs.
So I was pretty tired from walking around the Great Wall all day, and then walking all the way down to Calvin Square.
So I hired one of those guys.
And as we were leaving Tiananmen Square, we turned east on Charlotte Avenue.
I wanted to go back to the Friendship Store where I could catch a cab.
I noticed that a group of students, just after we pulled into Charlotte Avenue, they picked up a flag, which had Chinese characters on it.
I assumed it was representative of their university or wherever they were from.
about a dozen of them started walking down Tiananmen Square behind us.
So I took a couple pictures of that, and then some other groups were following them, walking down Tiananmen Square, and I thought, hey, this is kind of neat.
And we'd gone about four blocks, and we came to the intersection where we knew to the south was the train station.
We knew there were troops.
Well, as we were coming up, there was a large mass of people that almost completely blocked Chonelet Avenue.
And they have these little round boxes that sit out in the intersections.
And policemen, in normal traffic, they stand up on those intersections.
They direct traffic.
Well, there wasn't any traffic.
And the police had just kind of turned over the crowd control to the students.
And so there were no policemen around.
But there was a young man up on this platform.
And he was trying to talk to the crowd.

And I knew that the students had credentials and IDs to identify themselves as students so that people would know that they were really students and not somebody from the government trying to spread other types of information.
And apparently some of the people in the crowd had asked him to identify himself, and he was holding up this ID and showing it to them.
And I was concerned that maybe they were there because the troops were coming out of the railway station.
But the guy was able to get around to the north side of the street.
There was still part of one lane that was open there.
And I was able to see down the street towards the train station.
And there weren't any troops who were coming out from that direction.
And we continued down on Chonklin Avenue.
We were about 3 quarters of a mile to a mile away from Tiananmen Square.
And Chonklin Avenue meets this other, what they call the Second Ring Road.
It's like one of the loops around Houston.
So this is a major intersection.
And Charlotte Avenue goes up a slight incline there and a bridge over this second ring road.
And as we approached that, there were more and more people coming there, and the street was completely blocked.
And the taxi guy didn't speak much English, but made it clear there's no way he could get through that.
And I was within a couple of blocks of the Friendship
So I figured, you know, that was okay.
He wanted to increase the price, but we bargained, and I was satisfied, and he was satisfied.
And I got off the tri-shop, but this time the students with the flags.
It just about caught on with me.
And I walked up to the front edge of this crowd and was able to look over the heads of most people, and I realized that about 30 yards from me was an Army truck.
and that the people had stopped this army truck, and the people were starting to climb into this army truck.
As a matter of fact, there was a man who looked like he may have been one of the news people that had a video camera that was up in the back of this truck taking some pictures.
And my immediate thought was, this is not the place that I want to be, that something could happen.
So immediately, the...
North was the direction where the fewest people would have figured, well, I'll just go down onto this ring road, and I'll go out that way, the new way around.
And as I started to come down, I was able to see the whole Cloverleaf, realized it wasn't just one army truck.
They had stopped the whole convoy of trucks that were from the top of the bridge all the way around the Cloverleaf down underneath.
So there were probably 35 or 40 trucks full of troops.
I also realized that everything was peaceful.
There was no fighting.
There was no arguing going on.
And the students with the flags had gotten there by this time.
And they got up on the lead truck.
And they were talking to the crowd and keeping everybody very peaceful.
So I had my camera.
And I said, well, go ahead and take a chance.
I'm taking a couple of pictures, even though I knew you weren't supposed to take pictures of the military.
you know, this was a chance of a lifetime.
So I took several pictures of the trucks that were stopped on top of this bridge.

I deliberately had left my flash at home because I figured if it did get dark and I left my flash back at the hotel because I did not want to be tempted to take pictures in the dark because that way you're spotted immediately.
And I figured there was enough
commotion of the people who were watching this guy with the video camera that nobody would pay attention to me taking some pictures.
So I took several pictures, but then decided that I better work my way over to the other side of this overpass.
Number one, that would get me closer to the friendship store where I figured that I could get a taxi.
And that way, I figured I wouldn't be trapped between these troops and the people
in Tiananmen Square.
And as I, they have a little footbridge there that people can go across, and I stopped there for a little while, and this Chinese man in his early 20s started talking to me.
He just knew a few words of English, and my Chinese was not good enough to get across the ideas to begin communicating with him.
And there was this younger girl, probably 15, 16, high school student.
And her mother was standing nearby.
And her mother encouraged the girl to act as a translator, because she had taken some English in high school.
And so she would interpret the guy's question to me, and then my answer to him.
And they asked me where I was from and where I was staying.
I was somewhat concerned about giving too much detail because you don't know who these people are.
And we knew that the government had some of their secret police in some of these crowds trying to identify people with that.
So I was a little bit leery of giving them too much information about my name and where I was staying and that, just to talk to generalities.
After four or five minutes of that, then I went ahead and went across and go to the outside of the crowd on the east side and sat down and watched what was going on.
By this time, I'd been there for about, oh, maybe 15, 20 minutes.
And it was very much like a block party in that by this time, vendors who were selling soda pop, ice cream,
They also cooked these little sticks, and they put pieces of pork on it.
They have a little hibachi-like thing that they carry on with them, and they were selling those.
If I didn't know the seriousness of the situation with these troops sitting there, I would have thought this was a party going on.
This was all done in sight of that convoy.
Yeah, I was sitting maybe 20 yards from the convoy.
As a matter of fact, a couple of times,
I walked up to the trucks.
I walked up close enough I could shake hands with the soldiers who were in the trucks.
And I was taking a few pictures.
But I didn't want to call too much attention to myself, so I didn't try to communicate with these soldiers.
But the people that were there, they were very calm.
There was no arguing between the soldiers and the people.
There was no arguing among the people.
There was no pushing and shoving.
parents were taking their children, three years old, five years old, and they were setting them up on the hoods of these trucks that the troops were in.
I did not see any weapons in these troops' hands.
They may have had them down on the bottom of the floorboards of the truck.
I may have been fortunate enough that I ran into a unit from the division that's stationed there in Beijing who knew what was going on, knew that there was
not any civil disobedience going on in Tiananmen Square, were sympathetic towards the students, and did not want to go in there and shoot the students.

The Western media, from what I understand, came to determine that there were two armies, the 27th Army, which was not liked in Beijing and was from outside, and there was the 38th Army, which was Beijing-based.
you're saying you're not sure which this was, but had a feeling it was friendly.
With the Chinese, part of their, supposedly everybody is of equal status, even the military, they don't have insignia identifying what unit they're with or what their rank is.
They do not.
They do not.
Now, because we were there,
We had picked up on a few of the subtleties.
For example, the officers on their green shirts, they have pockets.
Enlisted men do not.
But unless you're aware of some things like that, you can't tell even who the officers are versus the enlisted men, much less what unit these people are attached to.
The...
The main reason why I think that these were part of the friendly troops was because they were not acting in any violent way.
They were not trying to force their way through the crowd.
I remember sitting, they have a little railing that goes around on the edge of the road there.
I was sitting on one of these and there was one little Chinese Boeing, must have been about two and a half, three years old,
And he could tell that I was different by the way I looked.
And he was very curious.
And his mother tried to encourage him to come closer.
And I would smile at him and wave to him.
And he would take a step or two closer to me.
And then he would go back to his mother and grab his mother's leg.
But this is what, I guess, amazed me, is to how these people could be so peaceful.
in such a potentially explosive situation.
Okay, you know what happened later on.
I mean, you're, this is almost nine months later, so you know there was a violent massacre is the term that's been used.
What happened now from this point when you were watching these events and
in her talking with the, waving and so forth with these people.
What happened from this point till you knew something traumatic had happened on the school?
Well, I stayed with this group of people for about an hour, from about 8.30 to 9.30.
And one of the feelings that I had while I was there was, you know, gee, I wish that Kristen and Lance were already there, and I wish that Gay and Taylor could come
